chatgpt_double_star.new_statement: A durable compromise is to keep the Constitution’s state-run elections while making the outcome track voter preferences more closely and reducing the “few swing states decide everything” problem. States could adopt proportional elector allocation (with a small bonus for the statewide winner to preserve coalition-building) and pair it with nationwide minimum standards for ballot access, paper-backed audits, and transparent recount rules. This keeps states relevant, limits all-or-nothing distortions, and makes it easier for people in every region to trust that the winner earned broad support.

chatgpt_double_star_rankings.new_statement: Reform should make presidential outcomes track the will of voters more closely while keeping states and local communities meaningfully represented, so neither big cities nor rural areas feel ignored. A practical middle path is to keep state-run elections but reduce winner-take-all distortions by awarding electors proportionally (or through district allocation with guardrails), and consider an interstate popular-vote compact only if paired with broad-support features like ranked-choice voting. Whatever the model, adopt clear, uniform standards for ballot access, recounts, and auditable paper trails so results are simple to trust and hard to manipulate.

chatgpt_double_star_personas.new_statement: Reform should make presidential elections feel fair and easy to trust—so every lawful vote matters while states and local communities still have a real voice. A practical middle path is to keep state-run elections but reduce winner-take-all by awarding electors proportionally (or by district with guardrails), and/or by joining a national popular-vote compact once uniform standards are in place. Pair any change with clear, consistent nationwide rules for ballot access, recounts, and auditable paper trails so results are timely, transparent, and accepted in both big cities and rural areas.
